header.title: OLAC Linguistic Data Type Vocabulary

abstract.p: This document specifies the controlled vocabulary of language resource types used by OLAC. The linguistic data type vocabulary describes the nature of the content of a resource from a linguistic standpoint.

section.heading: Introduction
section.p: Key points: two-level systems, multiple categories for a single resource, parallelism of the transcription and annotation subcategories.

section.heading: Linguistic Data Type
section.p: Each term of the controlled vocabulary is described in one of the following subsections. The heading gives the encoded value for the term that is to be used as the value of the code attribute of the Type.linguistic metadata element OLAC-MS. Under the heading, the term is described in four ways. Name gives a descriptive label for the term. Definition is a one-line summary of what the term means. Comments offers more details on what the term represents. Examples may also be given to illustrate how the term is meant to be applied.
A further label, Subterms, appears when the term permits more specific refinements. In such cases, the generic (top-level) terms may be chosen, or one of its more specific refinements.

term.name: Transcription
term.definition: The resource includes a transcription of a linguistic event.

comment.p: Phonetic transcription may be narrow or broad, and will typically use the International Phonetic Alphabet IPA in a standard encoding (e.g. Unicode-IPA, SAMPA). Phonological transcriptions are also classified here.
A prosodic transcription is a symbolic record of intonation, stress, tone or other suprasegmental features that is expressed independently of regular phonetic transcription.

term.name: Annotation
term.definition: The resource includes information which annotates some other linguistic record.

comment.p: A linguistic annotation is defined as structured linguistic information that is explicitly aligned to some spatial and/or temporal extent of some other linguistic record.

An example of a phonetic annotation is the TIMIT database, in which each element of phonetic transcription is associated with a range of samples in a digital audio file TIMIT. Phonological annotations are also classified here.

A morphological annotation is a morphological transcription where the component morphemes are aligned with some other linguistic record, such as an orthographic transcription or a speech signal. An example of morphological annotation is interlinear text with aligned morphemic glosses.

term.name: Syntactic annotation
term.definition: The resource includes aligned syntactic transcription.

term.name: Part-of-speech annotation
term.definition: The resource includes aligned part-of-speech tags.

term.name: Discourse annotation
term.definition: The resource includes aligned discourse transcription.

term.name: Dataset
term.definition: The resource is a structured set of data items.

comment.p: A dataset is a collection of items organized in a structured format for some specific research purpose. Examples of datasets are: a database of sentences illustrating deictic terms; an inflectional affix paradigm; a list of utterance tokens in a uniform context (e.g. "Say [pat] now.").
Subterms are the same as for annotation and transcription

A morphological annotation is a morphological transcription where the component morphemes are aligned with some other linguistic record, such as an orthographic transcription or a speech signal. An example of morphological annotation is interlinear text with aligned morphemic glosses.

A description is any description or analysis of a language. Unlike a transcription or an annotation, the structure of a description is independent of the structure of the linguistic events that it describes.

term.name: Orthographic description
term.definition: The resource includes documentation of a writing system.

comment.p: A paradigm is a tabulation of linguistic forms designed to illustrate one or more systematic contrasts.
A pedagogical description is a style of presentation intended for use in teaching people to use the language.

term.name: Comparative description
term.definition: The resource includes comparative or typological description.

term.name: Lexicon
term.definition: The resource includes a systematic listing of lexical items.

comment.p: This includes any resource that lists words or morphemes and defines them. It contrasts with a word list in that the definitions are complex (rather than being one-word equivalents) and the entries may include other information like part of speech, related words, and illustrative sentences.

term.name: Word list
term.definition: The resource includes a word list.

comment.p: A word list is a list of reference words in a major language for which the nearest equivalent word in a target language has been elicited (for instance, the Swadesh 100-word list).

term.name: WordNet
term.definition: The resource includes a semantic wordnet.

comment.p: Whereas a dictionary documents the meanings of words by means of definitions, a word net documents meanings by building a web of semantic relationships WordNet.
A thesaurus is a list of words or concepts arranged according to sense.

term.name: Terminology
term.definition: The resource includes a terminological lexicon.

comment.p: A terminological lexicon is a glossary of domain-specific terms. Examples are technical terminology, kinship terms, color terms, acronyms, ...

term.name: Bilingual Lexicon
term.definition: The resource includes definitions in another language.

term.name: Phonetic Lexicon
term.definition: The lexicon contains phonetic information, including pronunciation, phonology, stress, rhymes.

comment.p: Analytical information includes such things as morphological derivation, grammatically related forms, argument structure, ...

term.name: Text
term.definition: This is a primary resource: the object of study.

comment.p: A text is defined as any primary resource or research material, such as a literary work, film, or recording of natural discourse.

term.name: Narrative
term.definition: A monologic discourse: a history, tale, story, or recital.

comment.p: Types of narratives include historical, traditional, and personal narratives, myths, folktales, fables, and humorous stories.

term.name: Oratory
term.definition: "The art of the orator or of public speaking; the art of speaking eloquently according to definite rules, so as to please or persuade; rhetoric" (OED).

comment.p: Examples of oratory include sermons, lectures, political speeches, and invocations.

term.name: Dialogue
term.definition: An interactive discourse with two or more participants.

comment.p: Examples of dialogues include conversations, interviews, correspondence, consultations, greetings and leave-takings.

term.name: Singing
term.definition: The resource consists chiefly of language that is sung, rather than spoken.

comment.p: Examples of singing include chants, songs, and choruses.

term.name: Drama
term.definition: A planned, creative, rendition of discourse with two or more participants.

term.name: Formulaic
term.definition: The resource is a ritually or conventionally structured discourse.

comment.p: Examples of formulaic discourse are prayers, curses, blessings, charms, curing rituals, marriage vows, and oaths.

term.name: Procedural
term.definition: An explanation or description of a method, process, or situation.

comment.p: Examples of procedural discourses include recipes, instructions, plans, and descriptions.

term.name: Report
term.definition: An objective account of some event or circumstance.

comment.p: Examples of reports include news reports, essays, and commentaries.

term.name: Ludic
term.definition: Ludic discourse is language whose primary function is to be part of play, or a style of speech that involves a creative manipulation of the structures of the language.

comment.p: Examples of ludic discourse are play languages, jokes, secret languages, and speech disguises.

term.name: Unintelligible speech
term.definition: The resource consists of utterances that are not intended to be interpretable as ordinary language.

comment.p: Examples of unintelligible speech include sacred languages, speaking in tongues, and singing syllables (fa-la-la).
